awd_titl_txt: REU Site: University of New Mexico Department of Physics and Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics and Astronomy at the University of New Mexico.  The site will support eight undergraduate students per year in research projects in a variety of areas of physics. The main goal is to create motivation and excitement about STEM research and to provide skills and experiences which will increase the likelihood that the participating students will pursue a career in a STEM field. The site also aims to address a regional deficiency in that there is currently no REU with a primary focus on physics in New Mexico, a state with a large proportion of underserved minorities. Along with cutting edge research opportunities, there will be a professional development program that will educate the students in research conduct and expose them to the wide variety of STEM career paths their degree makes possible.  

The Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of New Mexico has a strong record of overall research funding and makes undergraduate education a top priority, including research. The intellectual activities of the REU will be characterized by the diverse research areas in the department, including quantum information, optical sciences, particle physics, astrophysics, biophysics, and geophysics.

por.por_cntn:
The REU program in Physics and Astronomy at the University of New Mexico enabled 26 undergraduate students to partake in a wide variety of research projects in physics and astrophysics, under the supervision of 13 different faculty members in the summers of 2018, and 2022 - 2023. In addition, remote summer research was undertaken by four undergraduates during the covid pandemic (2020 and 2021). Our purpose was to provide students the opportunity to participate in an active research environment of the type they would discover were they to take a job in a research lab, or continue their studies in graduate school. A special effort was made to attract and engage students who might otherwise have had limited opportunities to participate in scientific research, including women and others underrepresented in STEM fields. The program was successful in this outreach: more than half of the cohort being among this group. In addition, these summer students participated in real and significant advances in cutting edge research, resulting in more than a half dozen coauthored publications / conference presentations. Several of our REU participants have applied to our graduate program and some have begun graduate studies in our department. 

An important goal of our program was to develop a sense of belonging and camaraderie among the undergraduate researchers. This was achieved by weekly group activities such as seminars (on both scientific and career˗oriented topics), and weekend excursions. Both seminars and excursions included not only our REU researchers, but also our own undergraduate researchers, Society of Physics Students members, and participants in the University of New Mexico’s QU˗REACH undergraduate summer research program in quantum computation and measurement. We believe these efforts contributed to the high level of satisfaction our REU students had with our program and their remarkable scientific productivity.
